medical_history.chief_complaint: Fevers and abdominal pain typical of cholangitis.
medical_history.history_of_present_illness: The abdominal pain began one day prior to admission and was localized in the epigastrium. The patient developed fevers to 100.8Â°F throughout the night, which resolved by morning, but her pain worsened and radiated to the back, accompanied by nausea. She has a history of frequent intermittent abdominal pain, occurring weekly to monthly, seldom accompanied by fevers.
medical_history.past_medical_history: s/p cholecystectomy with bile duct injury; s/p roux-en-y hepaticojejunostomy and revision; recurrent right upper quadrant pain attributed to cholangitis; GERD; esophageal ulcerations; fibromyalgia; anxiety; hiatal hernia; arthritis; lactose intolerance.
medical_history.family_history: No history of GI malignancies. Mother with bipolar disorder and fibromyalgia. Father: hepatitis C, Type II DM. Two sons with ___ syndrome and another son with bipolar disorder.
